column5: -Ottawa Ankle Rules: 4 steps, bony pain on bilateral malleoli, base of the 5th, navicular
column6:
-~6-10 wks NWB, 
-Imaging + obtain WB clearance from physician
-Stregnthen other muscles ASAP (prox hip, knee, upper limb)
-Volume first before speed/intensity
column7:
-Active Ankle ROM
-Banded ankle plantarflexion, inversion, eversion, dorsiflexion
-Heel raises
-Single leg balance

column5:
-Widespread pain upon palpating tibia
-Running history: warm-up effect, low frequency of running but long duration
-Running assessment: high foot strike angle, low cadence, overstriding
-Runners will often push themselves through this so presentation is likely more severe and calcitrant.
column6:
-Run-walk intervals takes precedence over exercises. 0/10 pain. 
-Increase frequency & volume before speed
-Practice minimizing stride length, running softly and having a smaller stack and drop on shoes
column7: -A skips

column5:
-Dx includes bursaopathy and tendinopathy of the glute medius
-Painful palpation and compression along greater trochanter
-Single leg stance
-Pain on resisted hip abduction
column6:
-Focus on minimizing provoking positions (crossed legs)
-Assess if excessive hip adduction in running is a factor
-Rehab can push to 3/10 pain
-Focus on plyometrics
-Volume and hills first before speed/intensity
-If no improvement physicians may suggest cortisone: explain risks and promote rehab over injections.

-Side Lying Hip Abduction, Banded Crab Walks, Split Squat, Single Leg Squat

column5:
-Typically presents as hip pain in child 4-8 years
- Antalgic gait
- Restricted abduction/internal rotation.
column6:
-Urgent referral to surgical consultation for containment. 
-0 pain if planning to start running and having impact sports again. 
-Strengthen peripheral hip and lumbo-pelvic muscles.
column7:
-Side Lying Hip Abduction, Banded Crab Walks, Split Squat, Single Leg Squat
- Plyometrics: A-skips, C-skips, Bounding

column5: -Typically obsese adolescent with antalgic gait and restricted internal rotation.
column6:
-Urgent referral if you are diagnosing the initial complaint.
-Sports-Med Consult for Plan, Repeat Imaging
-0 pain during return to running
column7:
-Side Lying Hip Abduction, Banded Crab Walks, Split Squat, Single Leg Squat

column5:
-Pain with kneeling, deep squats
-Painful palpation along tibial tubercle
column6:
-Referral only needed if avulsion suspected or refractory
- Education: Tibial tubercle apophysitis, bump is not harmful
-Avoid loaded knee flexion past 60 degrees
- Focus on capacity instead of load as it is often difficult to maintain a healthy load management and social schedule for adolescents in school
column7:
-Biking
-Straight leg raise
-Spanish squats to 45 degrees
-Standing hip abduction, banded-crab walks

column5: -Important to differentiate from calcaneal stress fracture, as fat tissue is highly innervated.

column5:

column6:
-Challenging injury to manage since the surface area is so large and is exposed in hip flexion/compression (sitting) and in hip extension (standing, walking, running). 
-May require sleeping in prone or side-lying and avoiding any symptomatic sitting until pain is tolerable
-2/10 pain 
-Volume before speed
-Flat before hills

column5:
-Most frequent nerve entrapment; Morton's Neuroma. Compression of the interdigital nerves usually between the 3rd and 4th toes
-Squeeze test
column6:
-Examine shoe to see if the toe box or toe-off in running is a culprit
-Hallux valgus or a hypermobile 1st MTP may form calluses leading to a more narrow toe box and compression. 
-Decrease dorsiflexion, increase forefoot and interdigital mobility, try wider shoes
-0/10 pain before progressing
-Volume before speed
column7:
-Short foot exercise
-Banded toe abduction
-Single leg stand
-Barefoot running

column5:
-Rare entrapment: SN is formed by the tibial and common peroneal nerve but may mimic gastrocnemius pain but tends to radiate past lateral malleolis and the 5th MTP. 
-Neurodynamic Test: Hip flexion, knee extension, ankle dorsiflexion, foot inversion
-Running History: Burning pain...etc
column6:
-Modify footwear according to symptoms, heel lift if pain in dorisflexion or medial arch if in pronation
-Identify provocations in running assessment and remove compression
-0/10 pain before progressing
-Volume before speed
column7: -Nerve sliders: Hip flexion, knee extension, ankle dorsiflexion, foot inversion

column5:
-Rule out referred pain from sciatic nerve
-Neurodynamic Test: Hip flexion, knee extension, ankle dorsiflexion, foot eversion and toe extension
-Running History: Burning pain...etc
-Tinels'
column6:
-Modify footwear according to symptoms, heel lift if pain in dorisflexion or medial arch if in pronation
-Identify provocations in running assessment and remove compression
-0/10 pain before progressing
-Volume before speed
column7: -Nerve sliders: Hip flexion, knee extension, ankle dorsiflexion, foot eversion and toe extension

column5:
-Pain is usually a diffuse ache over the sinus tarsi
-Dorsiflexion + Eversion + Tinel's
-History of chronic ankle sprains is a risk factor.
column6:
-Rehab on ankle instability, proprioception 
-Modify footwear if needed
-0/10 pain before progressing
-Volume before speed
column7:

-Nerve sliders: Hip flexion + hip internal rotation, knee extension, ankle plantarflexion, foot inversion and toe flexion

column5:
-Entrapment may occur on the EHL and the extensor retinaculum, or osteophytes 
-Painful palpation on in the 1st web space
-Rule out compartment syndrome
column6:
-Footwear changes to avoid direct pressure 
-Try to reduce footstrike angle, hills 
-May require prolonged walk run intervals and sports med referal
-0/10 pain before progressing
-Volume before speed
column7: -Nerve sliders: Hip flexion + hip internal rotation, knee extension, ankle plantarflexion, foot inversion and toe flexion

column5:
-Neurodynamic Testing: Hip flexion + hip internal rotation, knee extension, ankle plantarflexion, foot inversion and toe flexion
-Tinel's
-Usually only the 1st branch LPN and it ends up on the quadratus plantae and abductor hallucis. Pain along the 4th and 5th toes
-Pronation tends to irritate it during running. Important to differentiate from plantar fasciopathy as the pain is superior to the aponeurosis origin
column6:
-Heel cups are helpful, ankle stability exercises are important as well as barefoot drills and running.
-Refer out if symptoms worsen or recalcitrant
-0/10 pain before progressing
-Volume before speed
column7:
-Nerve sliders: Hip flexion + hip internal rotation, knee extension, ankle plantarflexion, foot inversion and toe flexion
-Single Leg Standing + Band Pulled Laterally
-A-Skip

column5:

-Nerve glides may help desensitize tissue

column5:
-Branches of this nerve will branch out to 1st-3rd web spaces
-Pain along the medial heel and longitudinal arch, but more central
-Entrapment occurs at abductor hallucis or FHL either internally by hypertrophy of the muscle or external compression via footwear
column6:
-Desensitize tissue via modifying shoe or orthotics and increasing ankle stability, or improving running mechanics. 
-Hallucis rigidis may be a factor to MPN pain as well
-Assess footwear for a tight toebox
-0/10 pain before progressing
-Volume before speed

column5:

-Progress with volume, then speed, then hills
-Donut cushion for pain control

column5:
-Out of scope for physios. 
-You can probably perform an ankle-brachial index test on a treadmill until symptomatic and record the pre-post blood pressures.
column6:
- Refer to Sports Med who may refer to Vascular Surgery. 
-If surgery is indeed not an option, reduce intensity build volume. 
-Reorienting client goals is important to preserve limb integrity and quality of life.
